title: Protocol for the design, conduct, and evaluation of prime editing in human pluripotent stem cells
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
pegRNA and additional nicking sgRNA design for PE3
Timing: 2 h
        pegRNA design.
        
            For pegRNA design, we first use the Benchling CRISPR Design Tool (https://www.benchling.com/#[href=https://www.benchling.com/]) to find the best spacer sequence close to the editing locus. Once
            you log in your Benchling account, from the left navigation bar,
            choose Create>CRISPR>CRISPR Guides.
          
            After the target sequence is imported, Benchling will provide a list
            of guides targeting the region along with both on-target and
            off-target score based on algorithms for predicting on-target and
            off-target activities.
          
            Then we select the spacer with shortest distance to the editing site
            and the highest on-target and off-target prediction score.
            Generally, targeting protospacers more proximal to the desired
            targeting site yields higher editing efficiency. Therefore, we
            recommend starting with a protospacer that is positioned as close as
            possible to the targeting site.
          
            We then design the PBS and RT templates of pegRNAs using criteria
            previously published: PBS range from 8-15nt, RT template range from
            10-20nt, the first base of the 3′ extensions is not C.3[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib3]
Nicking sgRNA design for PE3.
      For PE3, an additional nicking sgRNA was designed using Benchling CRISPR
      Design Tool to target to the complementary strand at ∼ 60–100 bp
      downstream from the pegRNA cutting site.
    
Alternatives: other web tools are
      also available for pegRNA design such as PrimeDesign,6[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib6]
      pegIT7[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib7] and PE-Designer.8[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib8]
Scheme 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#sch1] shows the design of PE3 editing for the
      introduction of the N370S mutation in the GBA gene in hPSCs. For the GBA
      (N370S) mutation correction in the patient’s iPSC genome, the desired
      modification within the RT template is A.
    
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2999-Sch1.jpg
          Scheme 1. Schematics of pegRNA design and PE tools for the
          introduction of the GBA (N370S) mutation in hPSCs
        
          The pegRNA is composed of a protospacer sequence that targets the

region to edit, a primer binding site (PBS) and a reverse transcript
          (RT) template that includes the edit (in this case, N370S in GBA). The
          PE3 tools include a pegRNA, a PE enzyme (Cas9-H840A) fused to a
          reverse transcriptase, illustrated as a blue oval here) and an
          additional nicking sgRNA targeting the targeting the complementary DNA
          strand, located 61 bp downstream from the pegRNA nicking site.
        
PegRNA and nicking sgRNA plasmid cloning
Timing: 2–5 days
      This section provides a step-by-step protocol for pegRNA and nicking sgRNA
      cloning.
    
        PegRNA cloning (Scheme 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#sch2]).
        
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2999-Sch2.jpg
              Scheme 2. Schematics of pegRNA cloning
            
              pegRNA plasmid is cloned using Golden-Gate cloning strategy that
              assembling BsaI digested pegRNA backbone (Component 1), and three
              annealed double-stranded DNA fragments, including pegRNA spacer
              sequence (Component 2), pegRNA scaffold (Component 3), and pegRNA
              extension sequence consisted of PBS and RT template (Component 4).
            
Component 1: Digest pU6-pegRNA-GG-Vector (Addgene: #132777)
            plasmid.
            table:files/protocols_protocol_2999_1.csv
            Incubate at 37°C for 4 h in a water bath. A correctly digested
            pegRNA backbone will have bands at 2.2 kb and 800 bp (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]A). Isolate the 2.2 kb fragment using Qiagen Gel Extraction kit,
            elute using 20 μL water for a target concentration of 50 ng/μL. Keep
            in −20°C in between uses.
            
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2999-Fig1.jpg
                  Figure 1. Gel electrophoresis analysis in pegRNA cloning
                  process
                
                  (A) Digestion of the pU6-pegRNA-GG-Vector plasmid using
                  BsaI-HFv2.
                
                  (B) Colony PCR to identify positive clone following pegRNA
                  cloning.
                
            Anneal oligonucleotide parts (components 2, 3, and 4).
            Component 2: sgRNA target: primers 1 and 2 (variable in each
            cloning). For induction of GBA (N370S), it is listed below under
            pegRNA-GBA-10. For correction of GBA (N370S), it is listed below
            under pegRNA-GBA-4.
            table:files/protocols_protocol_2999_2.csv
Component 3: scaffold is always the same and is
            phosphorylated by IDT.
            table:files/protocols_protocol_2999_3.csv
Component 4: pegRNA extension, primers 3 and 4 (variable in

each cloning). For induction of GBA (N370S), they are listed below
            under pegRNA-GBA-10. For correction of GBA (N370S), they are listed
            below under pegRNA-GBA-4.
            table:files/protocols_protocol_2999_4.csv
            For each component, prepare the following reactions in 1.5 mL
            microcentrifuge tubes, put the reaction tubes in boiling water for
            5 min, and then let tubes gradually cool down to 25°C.
            table:files/protocols_protocol_2999_5.csv
Note: We order 25 nmole single
              stranded DNA oligos with standard desalting purification from IDT.
              Subsequently, we dissolve the powder with molecular water to
              achieve a concentration of 100 μM. Oligos for pegRNA scaffold
              (Component 3) must be 5′ end phosphorylated. No additional
              chemical modifications are needed for the other oligos.
            
            pegRNA assembly. Prepare the following reaction in 0.2 mL PCR tube.
            table:files/protocols_protocol_2999_6.csv
            Run the following program in the thermocycler.
            imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2999-Fx4.jpg
            Day 1, transformation. Transform 5 μL of the product obtained in
            Step 1.3 using MultiShot StripWell TOP10 Chemically Competent
            E. coli according to the protocol supplied with the competent
            cells. Upon transformation, spread all competent cells onto LB
            plates containing 100 μg/mL Carbenicillin.
            
Note: The pegRNA plasmids express
              ampicillin resistance gene. We use carbenicillin, a more stable
              ampicillin analog, on plates to select ampicillin-resistant
              colonies.
            
            Day 2, colony PCR. Pick two or three white colonies to be used as
            template for the following PCR. This PCR uses U6-Fwd as the forward
            primer and the reverse primer of Component 4
            (GBA-induction-extension-R or GBA-correction-extension-R), resulting
            in a 209 bp PCR product (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]B). The pegRNA
            cloning efficiency is generally high. Normally, there are tens of
            colonies on the plate. Picking two or three white colonies should be
            enough to get a correct pegRNA plasmid.
            
Critical: Red colonies are
              empty backbones and should not be chosen. The pegRNA empty
              backbone expresses the RFP insert which make the bacterial

colonies appear pink or red color. To clone the pegRNA plasmid,
              the RFP insert will be removed by enzyme digestion, resulting in
              the positive clones that appear white.
            
                Using a sterile pipette tip, pick half of the colony that you
                have chosen and pipette up and down into the tube, ensuring that
                the bacteria has been deposited into the mixture.
              
                Set up the following reaction in a 0.2 mL PCR tube.
                table:files/protocols_protocol_2999_7.csv
                Run the PCR using the following program:
                table:files/protocols_protocol_2999_8.csv
                Run an agarose gel electrophoresis to identified positive
                colonies (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]B).
              
                Use a sterile pipette tip to inoculate the other half of the
                positive colony into a 100 mL culture of LB medium supplemented
                with 100 μg/mL Carbenicillin. Incubate and shake the cultures at
                37°C for 16∼18 h.
                
Note: Colonies that fail to
                  produce a band of the correct size has not ligated properly.
                
            Day 3, isolate the plasmid DNA from the cultures by using ZymoPURE
            II Plasmid Midiprep Kit according to the manufacturer’s
            instructions.
          
            Sequence validation of pegRNA plasmid. Verify the sequence of each
            colony by Sanger sequencing using the U6-Fwd primer:
            5′GACTATCATATGCTTACCGT3’.
            
Note: The pegRNA cloning
              efficiency is generally high. Normally, there are tens of colonies
              on the plate. Picking two or three white colonies should be enough
              to get a correct pegRNA plasmid. Red colonies are empty backbones
              and should not be chosen.
            
Note: Make an endotoxin-free
              plasmid by using ZymoPURE II Plasmid Midiprep Kit according to the
              manufacturer’s instructions. A good quality and endotoxin-free
              plasmid is important for successful electroporation in hPSCs.
            
Note: The final products of this
              cloning process are pegRNA-GBA-10 (Addgene: #199271) and
              pegRNA-GBA-4 (Addgene: #199274).
            
        Additional nicking sgRNA cloning (Scheme 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#sch3]).
        
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2999-Sch3.jpg
              Scheme 3. Schematics of nicking sgRNA cloning
            
              Nicking sgRNA plasmid is cloned by assembling the BbsI digested

sgRNA backbone vector and the annealed sgRNA target sequence.
            
Component 1: Digest the LsgRNA (pSPgRNA) (Addgene: #47108)
            plasmid (backbone).
            table:files/protocols_protocol_2999_9.csv
            Incubate at 37°C for 4 h in a water bath.
            Purify the digested plasmid using the QIAquick PCR Purification kit.
            Keep in −20°C in between uses.
            Anneal oligos for target sequence
          
Component 2: sgRNA target: F and R oligonucleotides (variable
            in each cloning). We use the same Lsg-GBA-1+2 (Addgene: #199276) for
            induction of GBA (N370S) and correction of GBA (N370S).
            table:files/protocols_protocol_2999_10.csv
            Prepare the following reaction in a 1.5 mL microcentrifuge tube, put
            the reaction tube in boiling water for 5 min, and then let the water
            temperature gradually cool down to 25°C.
            table:files/protocols_protocol_2999_11.csv
            sgRNA assembly. Prepare the following reaction in 0.2 mL PCR tube.
            table:files/protocols_protocol_2999_12.csv
            Incubate the reaction at 16°C for 16∼18 h in a thermocycler.
          
            Day 1, transformation. Transform 2.5 μL of the product obtained in
            Step 2.3 using Mix & Go Competent Cells according to the
            protocol supplied with the competent cells. Spread one third of the
            competent cells on your LB plate with 100 μg/mL Carbenicillin.
          
            Day 2, colony PCR. There will be hundreds of white colonies on the
            plate. Pick two or three colonies to be used as template for the
            following PCR. This PCR uses U6-Fwd as the forward primer and
            GBA-sgRNA-R as the reverse primer, generating a PCR product that is
            274 bp long. Set up the following reaction in a 0.2 mL PCR tube.
            table:files/protocols_protocol_2999_13.csv
            Using a sterile pipette tip, pick half of the colony that you have
            chosen and pipette up and down into the tube, ensuring that the
            bacteria has been deposited into the mixture. Run the PCR with the
            following program.
            table:files/protocols_protocol_2999_14.csv
            Run an agarose gel electrophoresis to identified positive colonies.

Use a sterile pipette tip to inoculate the other half of the
            positive colony into a 100 mL culture of LB medium supplemented with
            100 μg/mL Carbenicillin. Incubate and shake the cultures at 37°C for
            16∼18 h.
          
            Day 3, isolate the plasmid DNA from the cultures by using ZymoPURE
            II Plasmid Midiprep Kit according to the manufacturer’s
            instructions.
          
            Sequence validation of nicking sgRNA plasmid. Verify the sequence of
            each colony by Sanger sequencing using the U6-Fwd primer: 5′
            GACTATCATATGCTTACCGT 3’.
            
Note: The sgRNA cloning efficiency
              is generally high. Normally, there are tens to hundreds of
              colonies on the plate. Picking two or three colonies should be
              enough to get a correct sgRNA plasmid.
            
Note: Make endotoxin-free plasmid
              DNA by using ZymoPURE II Plasmid Midiprep Kit according to the
              manufacturer’s instructions. A good quality and endotoxin-free
              plasmid is important for successful electroporation in hPSCs.
            
Note: The final product of this
              cloning process is Lsg-GBA-1+2 (Addgene: #199276).
            
PE tool delivery- electroporation
Timing: 3–4 days
Timing: ∼1 h (for step 5)
    
      This section describes how to deliver the PE tool into hPSCs for prime
      editing.
    
        Electroporation.
        
            hPSCs preparation. Maintain hPSCs in StemFlex medium. Routinely
            passage hPSCs at a ratio of 1:6 every 3–4 days using 0.5 mM EDTA.
          
            hPSCs digestion for electroporation. When the hPSCs reach ∼70%–80%
            confluency, aspirate the medium, wash the cells once with DPBS, and
            then add 1 mL Accutase and incubate at 37°C for 10 min. Add 3 mL of
            medium and detach cells by slowly pipetting up and down. Collect the
            cells into a 15 mL conical tube and spin at 120 g for 3 min.
            Aspirate the supernatant, add 1 mL StemFlex medium and count the
            number of cells using the Nexcelom Bioscience Cellometer K2.
          
            Prepare cells and reagents for one smaller cuvette electroporation

reaction using the 16-well Nucleocuvette Strip provided in the P3
            Primary Cell 4D-Nucleofector X Kit S:
            
0.5 × 106 cells.
                Mix the reagents: 16.4 μL P3 Primary Cell Nucleofector Solution
                and 3.6 μL Supplement 1.
              
                Plasmids: We simultaneously electroporated hPSCs with five
                different plasmids. These plasmids include a PE expressing
                plasmid, a pegRNA plasmid containing sequences for pegRNA
                spacer, scaffold and 3′ extension sequence (refer to
                Scheme 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#sch2] for detail), a nicking sgRNA
                plasmid, a p53DD expression plasmid to enhance the primer
                editing efficiency, and a puromycin resistance gene plasmid used
                for the enrichment of electroporated cells upon puromycin
                selection. Condition: 1 μg sgRNA plasmid (Lsg-GBA-1+2) + 1 μg
                pegRNA plasmid (pegRNA-GBA-10 or pegRNA-GBA-4) + 1 μg PE plasmid
                (pEF-PE2) + 1 μg PUC57-Puro + 1 μg p53DD plasmid (see
                Table 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl1]).
                table:files/protocols_protocol_2999_15.csv
                For our GBA induction lines, we electroporated:
                  1 μg pEF-PE2.
                  1 μg pegRNA-GBA-10.
                  1 μg PUC57-Puro.
                  1 μg Lsg-GBA-1+2.
                  1 μg p53DD.
                For our GBA correction lines, we electroporated:
                  1 μg pEF-PE2.
                  1 μg pegRNA-GBA-4.
                  1 μg PUC57-Puro.
                  1 μg Lsg-GBA-1+2.   1 μg p53DD.
                
Critical: The
                  electroporation process as well as the P3 solution are toxic
                  to the cells and should be performed as quickly as possible.
                  The plasmids should be pre-mixed prior to the start of the
                  electroporation. When the cells are pelleted, they should be
                  resuspended in the complete P3 solution first (P3 Primary Cell
                  Nucleofector Solution plus Supplement 1), then combined with
                  the pre-mixed plasmids. Afterward, the cells+plasmid mixture
                  should quickly be electroporated.
                
            Transfer the cell mixture to the Nucleocuvette Vessel using a P200
            pipet.
          
            Transfer the cuvette to the 4D-Nucleofector and electroporate the
            cells, select “Primary Cell P3”, Pulse Code, and press
            “Start”.
            
Note: Pulse Code for your
              hPSC lines can be optimized according to the protocol supplied

with the reagents. “CB-150” is the best code for hESCs and hiPSCs
              in our testing.
            
            Using a P200 pipet, transfer the cell mixture from the cuvette to a
            1.5 mL microcentrifuge tube containing 1 mL of StemFlex + CloneR
            medium. Rinse the cuvette once with a small amount of StemFlex +
            CloneR medium using the pipet and transfer to the 1.5 mL
            microcentrifuge tube.
          
            Transfer the 1 mL of cells equally into two wells of freshly
            Matrigel-coated 48-wells (0.5 mL cells in each well). We use one
            well of cells for Miseq analysis while reserving the other well as a
            cell stock. Place the plate in a 37°C, 5% CO2 incubator.
            
Note: Gently shake the plate back
              and forth and side to side to evenly distribute the cells. Avoid
              circular motions to prevent concentrating cells in the middle or
              around the edge of the well.
            
            At 24 h post-electroporation (Figures 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]A and
            2B), aspirate spent medium, then change medium by adding 0.5 mL
            StemFlex + Puromycin medium for each well.
            
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2999-Fig2.jpg
                  Figure 2. Representative images of the cells 24 h
                  post-electroporation, 24 h post-puromycin selection, and 96 h
                  post-electroporation
                
                  (A and B) Brightfield image of hPSCs at 24 h post
                  electroporation with PE plasmid cocktail. Puromycin selection
                  should be performed at this density.
                
                  (C and D) Brightfield images of hPSCs 24-h post-puromycin
                  selection. Remove the puromycin after 24 h.
                
                  (E and F) Brightfield images of hPSCs 96 h
                  post-electroporation. Cells should be at 70%–90% confluency
                  96 h post-electroporation. Scale bars, 10 μm.
                
            At 48 h post-electroporation (Figures 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]C and
            2D), wash one of the wells once with at least 0.5 mL DPBS. Aspirate
            the DPBS and add 40 μL of Sigma Lysis Solution for Blood. Lyse this
            well by scratching the bottom of the well horizontally, vertically,

diagonally. Transfer the lysis mixture to a 0.2 mL PCR tube and
            incubate at 75°C for 15 min followed by a 4°C hold. Move the
            contents to a 1.5 mL microcentrifuge tubes and add 360 μL of Sigma
            Neutralization buffer to each sample. The lysis will be used as PCR
            template for Miseq analysis detailed in step 4 as below.
          
            For the other well, aspirate spent medium, then change medium by
            adding 0.5 mL StemFlex. Change media daily until cells are ready to
            be passaged or frozen. Cells usually reach 80%–90% confluency at 72
            h–96 h post electroporation (Figures 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]E and 2F).
          
PE editing evaluation- Miseq analysis
Timing: 2–3 weeks
    
      This section describes how to prepare samples for Miseq, as well as the
      data analysis.
    
        Miseq sample preparation.
        
            Design a pair of primers to amplify the editing area by PCR
            (amplicon size can be around 300-450bp) (Scheme 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#sch4]).
            
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2999-Sch4.jpg
                  Scheme 4. PCR primer design for Miseq
                
                  PCR primer design for GBA (c. 1226A > G, p. N370S) mutation
                  induction and correction.
                
            PCR using Q5 High-Fidelity 2× Master Mix from cell lysate. Purify
            PCR products using the QIAquick PCR Purification Kit or QIAquick Gel
            Extraction Kit, and then submit for Amplicon sequencing (Illumina
            MiSeq system, Amplicon EZ service from Genewiz).
            
                Prepare the PCR mix, two tubes of 50 μL reactions for each
                sample.
                table:files/protocols_protocol_2999_16.csv
                This PCR uses primers GBA-PCR-F and GBA-PCR-R, making a PCR
                product size of 257 bp.
              
                Set the PCR program.
                table:files/protocols_protocol_2999_17.csv
            Perform PCR purification using the QIAquick PCR Purification Kit
            following manufacturer’s instructions.
            
                At the last step, elute using ddH2O starting with
                30 μL aiming for a concentration minimum of 20 ng/μL (a minimum
                of 500 ng is required for submission).
              
                Measure the concentration using a Qubit 4 Fluorometer.
                
Note: If there are unspecific

PCR products, using QIAquick Gel Extraction Kit is needed to
                  isolate the PCR band of the correct size.
                
            Submit your samples for Miseq using Genewiz’s Amplicon-EZ service.
            Receiving data will take approximately 2 weeks from submission.
          
        Miseq data analysis.
        
            Approximately 50,000–100,000 total reads per sample were collected.
            Alignment of amplicon sequences to a reference sequence is performed
            using CRISPResso29[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib9] (https://crispresso.pinellolab.partners.org/submission[href=https://crispresso.pinellolab.partners.org/submission]).
          
            Miseq analysis. Set these parameters in CRISPResso2 website:
            
Minimum average read quality (phred33 scale) is > 30.
                Exclude 15 bp from the left side and 15 bp from the right side
                of the amplicon sequence for the quantification of the
                mutations.
              
                Set the minimum homology for alignment to an amplicon to
                be > 60%.
              
                Provide the sgRNA and pegRNA targets and set the quantification
                window as -3.
              
                For quantification of point mutation editing, run CRISPResso2 in
                standard Cas9 mode. Calculate the editing yield as the
                percentage of reads containing the edit divided by total reads
                (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]).
                
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2999-Fig3.jpg
                      Figure 3. Miseq data analysis for a representative GBA
                      (N370S) induction experiment
                    
The data was extracted from the CRISPResso2 website.
                      (A) The number of reads input, after preprocessing, and
                      after alignment to amplicons. We use this data to check
                      the quality of the PCR product and the Miseq.
                    
                      (B) Alignment and editing frequency of unmodified and
                      modified alleles of pegRNA. The modified alleles include
                      the insertions, deletions, and substitutions at the
                      nicking site of pegRNA (-3), which we use for checking
                      indel frequency of the editing of pegRNA.
                    
                      (C) Alignment and editing frequency of unmodified and
                      modified alleles of nicking sgRNA. The modified alleles
                      include the insertions, deletions, and substitutions at
                      the nicking site of nicking sgRNA (-3), which we use for
                      checking indel frequency of induced nicking by sgRNA for
                      PE3.
                    
                      (D) Visualization of the distribution of identified

alleles around the pegRNA spacer. 31.05% of reads carried
                      the A-to-G change at the desired GBA (N370) locus.
                    
                For quantification of mutation correction in patients’ iPSCs
                that originally carried a heterozygous point mutation, calculate
                the correction efficiency as: (percentage of number of reads
                with the corrected nucleotide - percentage of number of reads
                with the mutant nucleotide) / 2 (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]).
                
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2999-Fig4.jpg
                      Figure 4. Miseq data analysis for a representative GBA
                      (N370S) correction experiment
                    
The data was extracted from the CRISPResso2 website.
                      (A) The number of reads input, after preprocessing, and
                      after alignment to amplicons. We use this data to check
                      the quality of the PCR product and the Miseq.
                    
                      (B) Alignment and editing frequency of unmodified and
                      modified alleles of pegRNA. The modified alleles include
                      the insertions, deletions, and substitutions at the
                      nicking site of pegRNA (-3), which we use for checking
                      indel frequency of the editing of pegRNA.
                    
                      (C) Alignment and editing frequency of unmodified and
                      modified alleles of nicking sgRNA. The modified alleles
                      include the insertions, deletions, and substitutions at
                      the nicking site of nicking sgRNA (-3), which we use for
                      checking indel frequency of induced nicking by sgRNA for
                      PE3.
                    
                      (D) Visualization of the distribution of identified
                      alleles around the pegRNA spacer. Correction % =
                      (63.20%–34.67%)/2 = 14.27%, which is the GBA correction
                      frequency for the patient iPSC that carried a heterozygous
                      GBA (N370S) mutation.
                    
                For quantification of indels at the pegRNA or sgRNA nicking
                site, calculate the indel efficiency as: percentage of (number
                of indicated indel-containing reads) / (total reads) (Figures 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]B, 3C, 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]B, and 4C).
